awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Drosophila evolutionary phenomics:  Public resource to support genotype-phenotype studies
awd_abstract_narration:
It is increasingly easy to sequence the genomes of species. The utility of genomic resources, however, is limited without knowledge of the complex developmental, physiological, morphological and behavioral traits that genes code for. Indeed, improving the ability to predict important traits (e.g., lifespan, disease) from knowledge of genotypes is one of the top priorities of modern biology. Much research uses the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, to map phenotypes onto genotypes. This project will begin by characterizing a set of traits that capture core aspects of life history for ~250 related species of Drosophila. These analyses will be complemented by mapping genotype-phenotype relationships across the 30 species of Drosophila with fully-sequenced genomes.  All data will be made available through a public database. This resource will enable strategic decisions about future genome sequencing priorities. Furthermore, the database will assist the integrated study of diverse life history traits in the context of both resource ecology and phylogeny. 

Using standardized protocols, all ~250 species of Drosophila and related genera (Samoaia, Scaptomyza, Zaprionus and Gitona) maintained by the Drosophila Species Stock Center will be phenotyped for a set of 18 morphological, behavioral, physiological and developmental traits, Collectively, these traits capture core aspects of sexual selection and life-history syndromes, in addition to providing characters relevant to ecological selection. These data form the basis for a valuable public database on Drosophila "evolutionary phenomics," along with accompanying phylogenetic resources. The data will also be used for two kinds of state-of-the-art comparative analyses. First, Bayesian phylogenetic modeling, applied to data for all species, will be used to evaluate rates of diversification and co-evolutionary dynamics among character states and across the clade using a range of alternative trait diversification models. Second, two complementary analytical approaches will be applied to all Drosophila species with fully-sequenced genomes to explore genotype-phenotype relationships for all traits, with the goals of identifying candidate genes underlying trait diversification and setting the stage for studies of the molecular evolution and genomic architecture of Drosophila biodiversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Phenotypes are simply traits: all of the morphological, physiological and behavioral traits, for example, that we can observe and measure to characterize differences among individuals within species, or among species. They are the manifestation of genes and gene networks - of the genome. The science of "evolutionary phenomics" characterizes biodiversity by examining how traits differ across related species in a phylogenetic context (meaning, with regard to a species tree). It is the study of evolutionary diversification.

 

Characterizing genome organization and evolution is a fundamental goal of biology. In recent years, technological advances have made the sequencing of genomes for different species relatively fast, easy and inexpensive. To make sense of this growing resource, it is imperative to now (1) characterize phenomes and (2) map the relationships between genotypic and phenotypic variation, both within and among species.

 

This NSF-EAGER award supported the Drosophila Evolutionary Phenomics (DEP) project, for which the foundational goal is to quantify about 30 different phenotypes (simple-to-complex) for about 150 species of fruit flies of the genus Drosophila. Traits include, e.g., sex-specific body size and life span, age-specific fecundity (relevant to studying reproductive senescence), female remating interval, sperm and egg dimensions, morphology of male and female reproductive organs and glands, ovariole number ejaculate size, courtship repertoire, wing surface area, etc. A second goal is to construct a robust phylogeny for all species included in the DEP project, which will facilitate all future analyses of the data. 

 

Drosophila melanogaster is arguably the most important biological model system. A handful of other, related species of Drosophilahave also been investigated to a decent extent. In contrast, very little is known about the vast majority of species. There is a National Drosophila Species Stock Center (NDSSC; Cornell University), which maintains living cultures and other resources for hundreds of Drosophila species and strains to provide to researchers around the globe. However, in our estimation, Drosophila is still underutilized as a system for studying comparative, evolutionary biology, and interest in funding the NDSSC by the NSF has waned. 

 

Phenotyping of additional species for the DEP project is ongoing, but will be completed in 2022. When completed, products of this project will include: (1) the most robust phylogeny to date for Drosophila species, (2) the most ambitious study (reported in a series of papers) of multi-dimensional trait evolution across any animal lineage, (3) groundbreaking analyses of genotype-phenotype relationships using comparative genomics and (4) a DEP public resource that includes all comparative phenotypic data, images and videos for all species included in the study.
